articles.headline: Nation Rich in Land Draws Workers From One Rich in People
articles.snippet: The influx of Chinese farm labor in Russia reflects the growing trade and economic ties between the two countries, one rich in land and resources, the other in people.
articles.abstract: The influx of Chinese farm labor in Russia reflects the growing trade and economic ties between the two countries, one rich in land and resources, the other in people.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSTANINO, Russia — When a Chinese investor bought a farm outside this village a few years back, he was pleased enough to name it Golden Land. The soil was rich, the sunshine and rain bountiful.

articles.headline: GoDaddy Goes Down, and a Hacker Takes Credit
articles.snippet: A supporter of Anonymous, the loose hacking collective, claimed responsibility for an attack that apparently brought down Web sites hosted by Go Daddy. The company’s site was down Monday afternoon, as were many of the Web sites hosted on its serve...
articles.abstract: A supporter of Anonymous, the loose hacking collective, claimed responsibility for an attack that apparently brought down Web sites hosted by Go Daddy. The company’s site was down Monday afternoon, as were many of the Web sites hosted on its servers.
articles.lead_paragraph: 1:07 p.m., Sept. 11 | Updated  GoDaddy now says its problems were not hacker-related.

articles.headline: In a Setback, Sanofi’s Dengue Fever Vaccine Falls Short of Its Goal
articles.snippet: Sanofi Pasteur’s vaccine results were called “a huge breakthrough” despite an effectiveness rate of only 30 percent.
articles.abstract: Sanofi Pasteur’s vaccine results were called “a huge breakthrough” despite an effectiveness rate of only 30 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The leading candidate to become the world’s first vaccine against dengue fever was only 30 percent effective in its first large clinical trial, dealing at least a temporary setback to efforts to control a disease that threatens half the world’s population.

articles.headline: Bets on European Bonds Paying Off for Funds
articles.snippet: With the extraordinary level of support from the central bank, mutual fund managers are reaping big returns on their purchases of bonds from Portugal, Italy, Spain and Ireland.
articles.abstract: With the extraordinary level of support from the central bank, mutual fund managers are reaping big returns on their purchases of bonds from Portugal, Italy, Spain and Ireland.
articles.lead_paragraph: When fear gripped the European markets in April, the money manager Robert Tipp decided to buy more Portuguese government bonds. He figured that European officials wouldn’t let the country turn into another Greece.

articles.headline: Plot Twist in the A.I.G. Bailout:  It Actually Worked
articles.snippet: As distasteful as the effort was, it should be clear by now that the rescue of the American International Group — often called a backdoor bailout of Wall Street — was a success.
articles.abstract: As distasteful as the effort was, it should be clear by now that the rescue of the American International Group — often called a backdoor bailout of Wall Street — was a success.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Some people just don’t like movies with happy endings.”

articles.headline: China Contractor Again Faces Labor Issue on iPhones
articles.snippet: Labor groups reported that vocational students were being forced to work at plants making iPhones as “interns.”
articles.abstract: Labor groups reported that vocational students were being forced to work at plants making iPhones as “interns.”
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — As Apple prepares to unveil the latest iPhone this week, the company’s manufacturing partner in China, Foxconn Technology, is coming under renewed criticism over labor practices after reports that vocational students were being compelled to work at plants making iPhones and their components.
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Charles Duhigg

articles.headline: As Low Rates Depress Savers, Governments Reap Benefits
articles.snippet: Low interest rates let governments keep their borrowing costs low, helping them live within their budgets without having to raise taxes or cut spending.
articles.abstract: Low interest rates let governments keep their borrowing costs low, helping them live within their budgets without having to raise taxes or cut spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: A consumer complaint is ricocheting around the world: low interest rates are eating away at savings.

articles.headline: Israeli Sharpens Call for United States to Set Iran Trigger
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu criticized the Obama administration for not setting clear “red lines” on Iran’s nuclear progress that would prompt the United States to undertake a military strike.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu criticized the Obama administration for not setting clear “red lines” on Iran’s nuclear progress that would prompt the United States to undertake a military strike.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel inserted himself into the most contentious foreign policy issue of the American presidential campaign on Tuesday, criticizing the Obama administration for refusing to set clear “red lines” on Iran’s nuclear progress that would prompt the United States to undertake a military strike. As a result, he said, the administration has no “moral right” to restrain Israel from taking military action of its own.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Isabel Kershner
